name: WASP-53
scenarioDescription:
The WASP-53 Exoplanetary System


Overview

WASP-53 is a star with 0.84 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.8 times its radius. It is located 660.50 light years away from the solar system.

WASP-53 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the WASP-53 system


WASP-53 b

WASP-53 b was discovered by the Multiple Facilities observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of WASP-53 b is 677.976 times the mass of Earth. The radius of WASP-53 b is 12.038 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, WASP-53 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


WASP-53 c

WASP-53 c was discovered by the Multiple Facilities observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 3.73 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of WASP-53 c is 5199.3 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, WASP-53 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system WASP-53, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Multiple Facilities.
